time_trend_data.indicator_description: Carbon monoxide exposure can be life-threatening or fatal. Maintaining surveillance of ED visits and hospitalizations allows us to understand the burden of CO-related health impacts in NYC and identify trends over time.

info.info_how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents hospitalized. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any of the following codes: E818, E825, E838, E844, E867, E868.0-1, E869.9, or having E868.2- E868.9 codes (regardless of the presence or absence of 986). After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM codes of T58.01, T58.11, T58.2X1, T58.8X1, or T58.91. For all years, excludes records with intentional or fire-related injury codes. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

*Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
info.info_source: New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates, New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

info.info_how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents hospitalized. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 for carbon monoxide poisoning and any unintentional fire-related injury code within the range of E890.0-E899.9. After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code of T58 for accidental or undetermined-cause carbon monoxide poisoning and any fire-related code within the range of X00-X08. For all years, excludes records with intentional injury codes. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

*Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
info.info_source: New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates, New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

info.info_how_calculated:
The number of NYC residents treated in an emergency department (ED), including those who were admitted as inpatients after being seen in an ED. Prior to October 1, 2015*, includes those with an ICD-9-CM diagnosis code of 986 or unintentional CO-related injury code. After October 1, 2015, includes those with an ICD-10-CM diagnosis code of T58 for accidental or undetermined-cause carbon monoxide poisoning. For all years, excludes records with intentional injury codes. The overall number may be larger than the sum of fire- and non-fire-related cases because it includes records that were not able to be categorized as fire- or non-fire-related. Counts are divided by the population using NYC DOHMH intercensal estimates and expressed as cases per 100,000 residents.

 

*Since October 1, 2015, all causes of emergency department (ED) visit and hospitalization are classified according to the ICD-10-CM classification system. Data from years prior to 2015 are not directly comparable to those after. Also, data from 2015 prior to the transition are not directly comparable to data from 2015 after the transition due to differing case definitions.
info.info_source: New York City DOHMH population estimates, modified from US Census Bureau inter-censal population estimates, New York State Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) Deidentified Hospital Discharge Data

summarize_data.indicator_description: Carbon monoxide exposure can be life-threatening or fatal. Maintaining surveillance of ED visits and hospitalizations allows us to understand the burden of CO-related health impacts in NYC and identify trends over time.
unreliability_text: ** Numbers <11 are suppressed as required by the Statewide Planning and Research Cooperative System (SPARCS) to protect patient confidentiality.
* Estimate is based on small numbers so should be interpreted with caution.
*** Number is suppressed for confidentiality reasons.
